div1.p: The American Association for Medical Progress briefly outlines the history of yellow fever and the Yellow Fever Commission, and concludes that animal experimentation is crucial in order to save human lives.

div1.head: Pamphlet: How Yellow Fever Was Conquered, American Association for Medical Progress, [n.d.]
div1.p:
YELLOW FEVER is one of the
most deadly diseases. It is
peculiar to tropical America. It
existed continually in Havana
and from there it frequently in-
vaded the United States, sometimes as far
north as Boston. In 1878, an epidemic of
yellow fever in the southern cities resulted
in 16,000 deaths and an economic loss esti-
mated at $100,000,000.

After the close of the Spanish-American
War, yellow fever broke out among the
American soldiers in Havana. A commission
to investigate its cause and transmission was
appointed, consisting of Major Walter Reed,
Dr. James Carroll, Dr. J. W. Lazear and
Dr. Aristides Agramonte.

Major Reed decided first of all to investi-
gate a theory, advanced twenty years before,
by Dr. Carlos H. Finlay that the disease was
transmitted by mosquitoes. The only way
of proving or disproving this theory was by
experimentation. At that time the lower

animals were thought to be immune to yellow
fever, so if experiments were to be tried at
all, they must be on human beings. Volun-
teers were called for and the Commissioners
insisted that they themselves should be in-
cluded. Every man knew that he was likely
to die, but he also knew that the experiment
might save thousands of his fellow men from
death. The volunteers permitted themselves
to be bitten by mosquitoes which had previ-
ously bitten yellow fever patients. Lazear
was the first to apply supposedly infected
mosquitoes to himself but the results were
negative. Later he was exposed to a con-
taminated mosquito, unintentionally, and died
in convulsions. Carroll almost died; for
three days his life hung in the balance. The
experiment was continued on eleven men, and
as two of them contracted yellow fever, Reed
felt justified in saying that the disease was
carried by mosquitoes.

Many, however, were not convinced, and
Reed and his associates decided to repeat the
experiments under conditions which would
leave no doubt. In a lonely place, a mile
from the nearest habitations, they established
an experiment station, and placed an armed
guard around it. It was named Camp La-
zear. An immune hospital steward brought
supplies from Camp Columbia but no other
intercourse with the town was permitted.

The first volunteer to be bitten by con-
taminated mosquitoes was John R. Kissinger,
who developed a typical case of yellow fever,
from which he later recovered. This showed
that the disease can be transmitted by the
mosquito.

To find out whether the disease can be
acquired by contact with contaminated ob-
jects, more volunteers submitted to a series
of most unpleasant experiences, in the course
of which they were exposed to the soiled
clothing and bedding used by men who had
died of yellow-fever. It was thus shown
that contaminated clothing and other objects
can not transmit the disease.

In another experiment, a small frame
building was put up and screened to prevent
mosquitoes from getting in or out. The in-
terior was divided into two unequal compart-
ments, separated by wire mosquito netting.
Two susceptible men were put into one side
of this building and one into the other com-
partment. There they remained for several
days, subjected in every way to exactly the
same conditions. When they had lived there
in good health long enough to prove that
they were not infected, Reed put fifteen con-
taminated mosquitoes into one of the com-
partments and declared that compartment to
be infected. The man in this infected com-
partment was bitten by mosquitoes several
times and in four days came down with yel-
low fever. Meanwhile the two men living
in the other compartment, breathing the same
air, remained perfectly well.

Reed, after simply removing the fifteen
mosquitoes, declared the infected compart-
ment disinfected. A non-immune soldier was
then placed in each compartment and the
two remained perfectly well for several days.

There followed a vigorous war upon mos-
quitoes. They were killed by fumigation and
their breeding places were sought out and

destroyed. In seven months, Havana was
free from yellow fever for the first time
since 1763, when yellow fever had become
continuously present in the region.

A few years later, General William C.
Gorgas started a similar campaign in the
Panama Canal Zone and within twelve
months abolished yellow fever there and
made possible the building of the Panama
Canal. This deadly disease with a few
others had cost the French 22,189 human
lives--one of the chief reasons why the
French abandoned the canal project.

Who will say that too high a price was
paid for this enormous saving of life? Who
will say that these men should not have
risked their lives to save millions from suffer-
ing and death? If we honor the soldier who
dies to save his company--a wounded com-
rade perhaps--how shall we honor Lazear,
who died to save a hundred thousand men?
There is a modest tablet to his memory in
Johns Hopkins University, and a great hos-
pital in Washington bears the name of
Walter Reed. But the service they rendered
to humanity is beyond estimate and beyond
reward.

If the bodies of men like this are not too
sacred to dedicate to such work as they per-
formed, is it too much to ask that the bodies
of a few rats or rabbits or guinea pigs shall
be dedicated to work of equal importance?
